content.description: This route takes the super thin seam right of the Bomb-Garden crack.
This route takes the crack in the corner through overhangs and finishes on the finger crack at the top
content.protection: The toprope for this route either takes lots and lots of webbing or a #8,#10,and #11 hexcentric.
content.location: On the left going up the advanced trail on sugarloaf

content.description: This route is short and sweet and has some fantastic moves on it. For the lead bring several crash pads and spotters to protect the first section to the stopper placement. It's a good idea to toprope the route first and work out the sequence as it's very specific thru the roof. An onsight would be super impressive on this one!! The entire route is left of Rays Bomb-Garden Crack but shares the same last move and protection.
content.protection: for the lead #3 stopper .5 camalot and a #2 tcu for the top crack and crash pad or twoÂ

content.description:
The Flying Frog area is an obvious area that has been climbed on for many years. Allthough it has been climbed for years and is located right on the trail it sees little traffic. The climbs are short, steep, and sweet here. As of the time of this writing "Flying Frog Roof" led by Brandon Snyder in 2009 has still not seen a second accent!! The trad climbing here can be chllanging because of the short nature of the routes. A crash pad is recomended for padding the base when leading the roof. 

 The Slab Wall has great moderate top rope routes as well. Be considerate when climbing on the slab as it is right on the trail, try to keep gear and ropes clear of the trail best as you can.
